segments.text: What were the opinions or maybe even their evaluation of veterinary medicine of the previous presidents and provosts before I went to the president's office?
Starting with, I think, the team of Dr. Vandiver, who was present when I came back here, and in the provost's office,

with Chuck McCandless and Gordon Eaton, there was a real support of veterinary medicine, because I think that they had been in the position long enough to realize that this was the only veterinary medical program in the state of Texas, and that it was one of the top in the nation, and if it were to remain top in the nation,
that it was going to require considerable attention.
It had to have increased funding.
It had to have some new facilities.
And one of the greatest chores I had when I was still back in the veterinary medical school was to get the new large animal teaching hospital and the new research building.
And the college could not have been a top university without those and was
going to be on probation.
Who deserves most credit for bringing that into reality?
Well, I, you know, you don't want to say I did something, but George Shelton and I went to the mat on those facilities, and we finally convinced the university, we finally convinced Ed Peel,

who was Vice Chancellor for Facilities and Planning and we convinced Mr. Weisenbaker and the other members of the Board of Regents and actually took them to see the facilities and how antiquated and old they were and that it was absolutely essential that we have them.
Who were the, on the Board of Regents, who started out being the strongest proponents?
I don't know that we really got into that until we had convinced the building committee and Mr. Weisenbaker.
And once we had done that, it was a pretty easy sale.
We had to also convince Dr. Atkinson, who was chancellor.
And he saw the need.
And of course, being a premier scientist, he clearly knew that the research component was so critical to us.
and he became one of our staunch supporters and I think really helped gain the support of the Board of Regents.
All right, then after President Vandenberg, who's next?
Bill Mobley followed him.
Oh, okay.
And before you went over to work with him, what did you think his level of concern for veterinary medicine was?
Well, Bill probably did not know much about veterinary medicine.
But having sat on the dean's council and having been given a background, at least from the
I guess, communication process and interchange that would occur there, had a great appreciation for what that program meant.
I think not only to Texas A&M University, but to the system and to the state.
And he became a very strong supporter.
And of course, with my background, he would rely upon me, but we were both very careful to never do anything that would
signify that we might be given preference to veterinary medicine because we weren't.
It was just one of the strong programs that had to continue its advancement and had to have the kind of funding required to do that.
And it was looked at as a program that would not be a drain but a complement to A&M, and particularly since it had now become line item.
And then he was able to be a great spokesperson for the program.
Who in Austin were the greatest help in that line item status?
Bob Bullock was a real help in that.
The coordinating board was, and Ken Ashworth really did help us a lot.
Jimmy Bond was vice chancellor and handled a lot of the state affairs.
He really did help.
And just many of the legislators like Rick Perry, for instance, was one that really did help us.
And most of, even
Senate Finance Committee, the House Appropriations Committee.
Once they had the endorsement of the University and the Chancellor, they had the endorsement of the Coordinating Board and the Legislative Budget Board.
We probably had to work hardest in convincing the Legislative Budget Board than any.
But once they did and they saw the parallel to the medical and dental schools, then they became very supportive.
All right, and you're in this notch as the assistant to the president, chief of staff, and executive for how long?
I was only in that role for one year.
And Gordon Eaton and Chuck McAnus leave to go to Iowa State.
And Don McDonnell, his title was vice president.
Academic, Vice President for Academic Affairs and Provost.
Okay, and then what was your title?
Or was it the same under him?
No, mine changed.
Mine was given the title of Senior Vice President and Provost.
And that was purposely done to signify that it was the second administrative officer of the university.
We were already laying the groundwork for
the endowment campaign.

That was the vision that Bill had knowing that long term that we had to rely probably less on the available university fund and what the state appropriation was and begin to look at what other universities had to do many, many years earlier and that was to have a great increase in our overall endowment.

So knowing that he was going to be out a lot with that campaign and dealing with an external constituency and the alumni, the former students, and then also to devote a lot of his time to the legislative side of the university to increase and help our state funding.
Because we were at a time where, quite honestly, state funding was not increasing at the same as it had been in the past.

So with all of those in mind and knowing that a lot of the heart of the university is the academic area anyway, he changed the title to Senior Vice President and Provost so that when he was gone, the shoulders, the responsibilities of the presidency would be in my lap that day or those days.
Right.
So you were a staff member.
officer for him, the deans did not report directly to you?
Yes.
Oh, they did?
Yes.
All the deans reported to me, all the libraries, student admissions, all the vice presidents, the research program, the faculty.
What about your, on a diagram chart, what was your relationship to Donald McDonald then?
Oh, I replaced him.
Oh, you replaced Donald.
Donald left and went to American University in Egypt.
In Egypt, okay.
And then I went through the whole selection process and was his, I succeeded him.
All right, I'm confused then.
Eaton?
McDonald followed.
All right.
And Eaton is there for about a year after you for your first year?
No.
No.
McDonald had been named
provost a year or two before I became executive assistant and chief of staff.
Oh, I see.
Okay.
Describe the working, the leadership style of Bill Mobley and his greatest joys and his greatest pet peeves or frustrations.
Well, it was interesting because he was one of the premier administrators that I have ever worked with.
I would characterize Bill as a visionary leader who tried to select competent people and delegated to them and held them accountable.
He had a real vision for A&M.
He had an incredible loyalty.
He was also a people person who really cared about the people that he led.
His greatest joys had to come
from the success of the endowment campaign, the success that we had in elevating all of the academic and research programs at this university.
The greatest heart burns that he and I both shared would have been having to handle the athletic problems and we both went through the times where

The university was under intense scrutiny from investigative reporters and newspapers and all kinds of questions about a lot of the business processes and things that were happening even in the border regions.
So those were the more difficult sides of it.
But the great accomplishments in times of real fruit-bearing
related to really the heart of the university, and that would be the academic side.
In terms of personal things, what were his, did he have any pet peeves, special kind of coffee?
Well, it was interesting because, yeah, he did.
One thing that I, I was always afraid to ride with Bill because he, the first several years he smoked a pipe,
And he would be trying to smoke his pipe and light it, talk on the phone and drive all at the same time in Houston.
And I would sit there with pushing my foot in the floor many times, worried about him.
And Bill was one of those people, too, who really got hyper-focused when there was an issue or when there was an opportunity.
And I never will forget coming back from Houston one day.
We had been to Austin and back the day before, and we'd gone to Houston, and we get right outside South College Station, and we stop at this red light, and his car runs out of gas.

And I just envisioned, here we are, the president and senior vice president and provost of Texas A&M University pushing his car to a fill-in station, which was fortunately only about 100 yards up the road.
And for some reason, he tried to crank it one time.
It started, he gave it a big push, and he gave it enough gas that we rolled in dead, dead engine, into the gas station.
Oh, no, that's a good one.
That's a good one.
All right, what about his pet, Joey?
Is that something he really enjoyed?
Bill really enjoyed the interaction with students.
He had a real heart for students, and he really enjoyed the times that he had with them.
We had a lot of events for students at the house, the president's home, at the MSC.
Bill loved to make speeches, and I think those were real times of joy.
Did anybody prepare them for him?
A lot of times Mary Helen Bowers would prepare.

Bill was notorious about deviating from the text in fact he usually got up and would make the statement to the crowd that my wife says I make two mistakes with all my speeches one is I deviate from my text and the second is I return to my text he was notorious about doing that but he always had a message and he always had
a speech that reflected the good of what Texas A&M was about.
Were the speeches normally written out in full or just an outline of topics?
Most of his were written out in full, but he frequently would just put the notes in his pocket and go extemporaneously.
Who would he turn to most often for input, suggestions, opinions?
The Vice Presidents.
We had the President's Council meeting every Monday.
And he would turn to all of us in those situations.
If it were an academic matter, clearly he would call me.
If it were a student matter, he clearly would call John Colas, who was vice president for student affairs.
If it was a matter of operations and administration, it was Robert Smith at that time.
So he was a very trusting individual and a very delegating individual.
And Bill was a person who rarely praised in private, but he had a great ability to praise the people around him who were giving contributions to the overall good of the university in public.
You never knew when it was going to come.
For example?
He would do it.
For example?

If it perhaps would be a group of former students or a group in one of the college's development council and I was there and we'd done something in the academic side that was going to make a difference, he would just give credit maybe.
And he was good at remembering to do that.
Of the groups that he spoke to, which ones do you think he enjoyed speaking with most and least?
Probably he enjoyed speaking to former students groups the most, as well as one other.
Bill had this vision also of the international dimension coming into Annan University.
And he should be given credit.
for infusing that dimension into every segment of this university.
That's a good point.
And he loved to talk to groups about that particular topic and what it meant to the future of this university.
Probably the least would be the same as mine.
Some of the legislative budget hearings, those are probably the hardest and most grilling.
Can you give an example of?
Oh, man, we went through one time in the House Appropriations.
It seems like that the group was in a nasty mood most of the time for some reason that was beyond us.
And they had a tough chairman at that time.
And we followed the University of Houston.
And the University of Houston had had some questionable things that had arisen with a letter that had been sent out
regarding even a member of the House Appropriations Committee.
And we followed them in giving our budget presentation.
And they were not in a good mood when we walked in.
And I remember that to this day.
We called them when we left.
We said, that wasn't a hearing, that was an inquisition.
And those were real challenging times.
During those years, you all were quartered where?
Where were the key demonstrators?
I moved a lot.
when I became chief of staff then when I became president I moved back to the Koch building and then about a few months later or no more probably than a year then I moved to
to the administration building on the front of the campus.
And I was able there to bring all of the other academic units in with me, with the exception of research.
The Chancellor's full operation moved to the headquarters off campus next to Hilton.
And then, of course, when I became president later, I moved back to .
So I moved a lot.
Let's see.
Describe your vice presidential level colleagues at that point under Dr. Mobley.
Robert Smith was vice president for administration and operations.
Did he predate you?
All of them predated me.
John Coldis was vice president for student affairs.
Bob Walker was vice president for development.
And which one am I leaving out?
That was it.
That's it.
We had a very small upper administration for the side university.
How often did you all meet?
We met every Monday morning at 8 o'clock in the president's office.
What was the nature of those meetings?
Everything that could come up and every issue that was facing us
We had an agenda.
We had an agenda.
We had an agenda.
We had an agenda.
We had an agenda.
We had an agenda.
We had an agenda.
Were you encouraged to be candid in those sessions?
Oh, absolutely.
We were encouraged to be candid and nothing held back and share things that needed to be shared.
Can you share any anecdotes of high points, low points, happy moments or sad moments?
Well, a lot of happy moments clearly were times where we had made a legislative success, where we had been able to recruit

a strategic administrator, a dean, a department head, where maybe we'd gotten a substantial research grant that meant a lot to the university, where we had gotten maybe a new facility that we had proposed to the Board of Regents.
Just those things that made a big difference, or we'd gotten a big development grant to the university, or somebody made an enormous gift.
Those were the better things that happened.
The harder things were some of the things that happened at that time.
We had some corps issues.
There were some incidences of harassment of women in the corps that had come to surface.
We had the NCAA issue.
And then some of the other kinds of things that had been
developing with the Dallas Morning News and investigative reporting about there was an impropriety or something somewhere.
You know, just those things that when an operation is that huge, you want everything to go well, to not be questioned.
and that there would be no downers and all positives, but that is never going to be the utopia that you would reach.
And Dr. Atkinson was the chancellor during that time.
Dr. Atkinson was the chancellor during almost all of that time, yeah.
And he was a positive factor.
He was a very positive factor and very supportive.
It was good because
Dr. Mobley had a great partnership with Dr. Atkinson, and I had a great partnership with Dr. Mobley and Dr. Atkinson.
So the three of us were able to form a very close team of looking at the overall academic focus and programs and statue of the university with the same kind of goals.
So we were on the same page.
And Dr. Atkinson was fighting for us in Washington, he was fighting for us in Austin, and he was very astute at doing it.
And many times, too, when we would go to the Board of Regents, for instance, we were all three working together on the issues, and there was a consolidated, unified effort of what we were doing.
walk through this whole athletic problem?
How did it begin and so forth?
Well, there were more than one.
I got in on the tail end of the Jackie Sherrill time, and Bill had to take a strong stand there.
So as Jackie was being terminated, I came into the president's office.
Now what was the central issue of the Sherrill problem?
Well, that there were improper payments made to some student athletes from Dallas Boosters.
I don't know all of the details because I really did not handle that one.
Then when I was executive assistant and chief of staff,
And I believe before I had become senior vice president and provost, there was a basketball issue.
And Bill had to deal with that one.
I did not.
And then as Bill was leaving the president's position to become chancellor of the system, and I was taking over as president of the university,
it was right in the middle of the last NCA issue where eight student athletes had been paid
for working when in fact a lot of times they were just sleeping on the job and that had surfaced.
Now these were football?
These were all football players.
And the head coach at that time was?
R.C.
was head coach.
Oh, okay.
And he was upset about it as you could imagine because he had made a pledge and a commitment that this would never happen, this would be a clean program.
And there was no institutional involvement whatsoever.
It was all outside and alumnus involved in it.
Do you feel comfortable in describing your opinion of the attitude that Bill Mobley took about these violations?
I would be very honored to express what Bill

had as an opinion on it because he took only the highest road of integrity that could be taken and quite frankly he and I worked for all those years together as hard as we could to put in a model program that was far and above the NCAA requirements because we could not afford to have any kind of
problem arise.
And we had the cooperation of everyone.

And I would venture to say that even today, a lot of the things that other universities are now doing are things that are modeled after the things that were put in place through those three times of real trouble.
What were some of the things y'all put in place?
Well, number one was that the academics would be monitored very carefully.
There'd be no questioning those.
The student athletes had to register what cars they had.
They had to then register where they would be working.
They had to sign when they signed on a letter of intent at A&M that if they broke the rules themselves that they would lose their scholarships.
We had compliance officers which were new at the time.
I mean there were so many new things put in place and completely upheld by the athletic council.
And you hate to have to do that and to be so rigid and so almost bureaucratic quite frankly.
But we had no option because we could not have another issue and we didn't want anything
to happen in our program.
We had a big education system put into place where we would actually try to educate the former students and anyone of what they could and could not do.
So it was rigid.
Am I correct in here having heard the report that on one occasion Dr. Mobley as president in a real showdown over the Jackie Sherrill matter
turned in his resignation if they did not, if the board did not support him.

If the board had not supported him when he first came into the presidency, and this was only a few months, in his decision for Jackie to be removed because of what he had done, he would have resigned as president.
He drew the line in the sand.
And that was his attitude from then forward, that A&M would only run
a clean program and have the utmost integrity in it.
I'm not going to ask the negative on this one.
Are there any regents at that time that are notable for their support of the athletic standards?
I wasn't in the position at that time.
to have seen and to have known.
But clearly they all had to come to the forefront of supporting what we put in place.
Was Tom Adair the chairman of the Athletic Council?
Tom Adair was chairman of the Athletic Council.
What about his role in any of it?
He was strongly supportive of everything that we did.
And had really over a period of time developed a presence on the national scene.
So with that national scene presence he had,
you can imagine his heart was also to have a model program here.
And that was our goal.
Look, A&M is going to have a model program.
I'm proud to say that Jarvis one day asked me if they needed another member on the athletic council.
And I told him that I thought Tom Adair would be a very good person.
And as far as I know, he's still the faculty representative.
He was chairman the whole time I was in all the high level positions.
And I think still is.
Yeah.
Mobley moves to the chancellor position.
Am I correct in remembering that one of the factors that caused Perry Atkinson to step aside as chancellor was his wife's health?
I don't know all the reasons, but I think that clearly that was one of them.
His wife had what proved to be fatal health problems, and I knew that he needed and wanted to spend more time with her.
We hated to see him step out of that role because he had really been a tremendous leader for not only the system, but also we were the benefactor of what he had done.
All right.
And then Dr. Mobley then becomes the new chancellor, is that right?
He becomes the new chancellor, and then I was named interim president.
All right.
Describe any of the circumstances you can about how that came about, how you learned about it, and so forth.
Well, when Bill was named chancellor, I don't even recall
But I think he is the one that called me and asked if I would serve as interim president.
And then I was probably called by the chairman of the board to ask if I'd be willing to serve in that role.
And all of this was happening in a rather short period of time.
And I immediately said yes because

I had had such a part, I felt, of putting in place so many things as Senior Vice President and Provost in the academic area and the research area and the graduate student area that I wanted, in working with the endowment campaign, that I didn't want to see a hiccup or a...
